We filmed this video last year/pre-pandemic and the message is so spot on to our current situation. Our district works to build empathy so our educators are aware of what some "students are dealing with when they're not in our classroom." We might not have students in our buildings, but they're on our teachers' screens and we are still "valuing them, and we are loving them, and we are growing them."

Rest assured that we have a plan and we will work to connect with each and every one of our students. "Schools are systems. Systems have culture. There are some cultures that are left out in our system. And without a deliberate and specific plan to address those people that are left out we will be flapping in the wind." #DiversityRising #MiddieRising

Today we'd like to shout out one of our own! Michael Diehl is a paraprofessional at Middletown High School and he's a competitor in the Strongest Disabled Athlete, powerlifting, and Strongman competitions in both the United States and Europe.
‚¨áÔ∏èFrom Mr. Diehl:
"I lost my arm as the result of an on duty accident when I worked for the City of Franklin as a Firefighter/ EMT. I didn't get into strongman and powerlifting competitions until after I lost my arm. I also played semi pro and arena football. I coached peewee football in Franklin for 7 years until we just moved into Madison, where I help coach the 6th grade football team. I was born near Cleveland, but grew up in Phoenix, Arizona. I also served 4 years in the Navy as an engineer aboard the USS Tarawa and USS Duluth. When I peak for a competition, I usually weigh around 290 lbs at 6'2.5" tall."

Amazing! He also recently had a birthday, so wish him a happy birthday too! üí™üéÇ
